title: Can you put a lien on the bankruptcy plan?
question: I had a civil trial and got a judgment. Now the debtor has to pay my money back- the money he originally took from me. But now he has filed for chapter 13 bankruptcy. Could my ex-attorny put a lien on the debtors repayment plan?
answers: There are certain exceptions to a bankruptcy discharge. Fraud is one of these exceptions. While you cannot put a lien on anything while the automatic stay is in place, you should contact counsel to see if you might have grounds to file an adversarial proceeding to except your claim from discharge or objecting to confirmation of tje Chapter 13 plan. In addition you should file a proof of claim. All of these things have tight deadlines, and time is of the essence.
The best thing for you to do is set an appointment with a local bankruptcy attorney so your rights are protected in the bankruptcy court.

You cannot put a lien on the CH13 plan but you can file a proof of claim. Carefully read any information you received regarding the bankruptcy so you don't miss the deadline to file the proof of claim.

Nope, you don't put a lien on a Chapter 13 plan. You file a proof of claim. If you were listed as a creditor, and received notice of the Chapter 13 case, perhaps you received a blank proof of claim form, with instructions on how to fill it out, as well as how and where to file it. Go through the papers you received [if any] from the bankruptcy court regarding the Debtor's Chapter 13 filing, then go see a lawyer.
Proof of claim needed. Hire a lawyer.
No. Bankruptcy changes how and what you will be paid.
No, absolutely not. You or your attorney can file a proof of claim in the debtor's ch13 case and you will be paid according to the plan's terms as confirmed by the court.

Nope, but the atty may have a lien on the funds that you are to receive from the debtor.

if the amount is sufficient HIRE A LAWYER to assess your rights
No-- IF this is a 13 you will get paid back according to the plan. If it is a 7 you will see nothing, except a tax write-off.
